Stephen A. Cook

General

Stephen Cook was born on December 14 in 1939 in Buffalo, New York. With expertise in mathematics and computer science Cook has made his contributions on complexity theory and its proof for which he received a Turing Award in 1982. Currently, he is a professor at the University of Toronto, in the Department of Computer Science and Mathematics.

Contributions

Cook studied mathematics at the University of Michigan and later got his master’s and PhD from Harvard University.
In his PhD, Cook researched the complexity of function with main focus on multiplication and in 1971 he wrote a paper with the title "The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures”, where he formalized the notion of polynomial-time reduction and NP-completeness. Cook proved the existence of NP-complete by proving that the Boolean Satisfiability Problem was NP-complete.
This theorem is known as the Coop-Levin theorem as it was also proven by Leonid Levin in the Soviet Union.
In 1966 he became an assistant professor at Berkeley University at the faculty of mathematics.
After he was denied reappointment in 1970, he went to the University of Toronto and as an associate professor of the Department of Computer Science and Mathematics. In 1985 he became a Distinguished Professor.
In 1975 Cook published a paper named "Feasibly Constructive Proofs and the Propositional Calculus" in which he introduced the Equational Theory PV, which aimed to formalize using polynomial-time concepts in proofs.
In 1979 he formalized p-simulation and efficient propositional proof systems in the paper "The Relative Efficiency of Propositional Proof Systems" that was copublished with one of his students, Robert A. Reckhow.
In 1982 Cook won the Turing Award for his theory of complexity. He received multiple medals for his contributions as well as being appointed a Fellow for the Royal Society of London, Royal Society of Canada and ACM.
In 2015, Cook was named an Officer of the Order of Canada.

Turing Award 1982

In memory of A.M. Turing
